column1: Jeju (Jeju-si; Korean pronunciation: [tɕe̞.dʑu]) is the capital of the Jeju Province in South Korea and the largest city on Jeju Island. The city is served by Jeju International Airport (IATA code CJU).
Located on an island off the Korean Peninsula
column3: warm weather during much of the year. The city is a well-known resort
column4: with prestigious hotels and public casino facilities. In 2011
column5: 9.9 million passengers flew between the two cities of Seoul and Jeju
column6: making the Gimpo–Jeju route the world's busiest passenger air route. Jeju welcomes over ten million visitors from mainland South Korea
column8: and China every year. The population of Jeju City is 486

column1: The area of the city has played a central role in Jeju since before recorded history.  The Samseonghyeol
column2: holes from which the three ancestors of the Jeju people are said to have come

column1: The city has grown quite rapidly since the 1970s. Shin Jeju (신제주)
column4: up the hill from the airport and houses many government buildings. The thatched roof buildings that were common throughout the city until the 1970s are gradually disappearing.

column1: The city was separated from Bukjeju County in 1955. However
column2: in 2005 Jeju Province voters approved a proposal to merge the city with Bukjeju County
column3: also merging Seogwipo with Namjeju County to create two large cities directly administered by the province. That change was put into effect in July 2006.

column1: In 2012 Sang-Oh Kim became mayor; he was formerly the Jeju regional president of National Agricultural Cooperative Federation.
Jeju City is the principal transportation center for Jeju Province. It is home to the island's sole airport
column2: Jeju International Airport; the Jeju-Seoul route is the world's busiest airline route.In addition
column3: its port is the largest on the island
column4: serving the great majority of passenger and cargo vessels that visit the island. It also stands at the center of the island's road network. To travel throughout the city and island
column5: various buses are available and affordably priced
column7: 000 won (0.90 USD) for one ride. A bus ride from Jeju City to Seogwipo (the second largest city on the island) is typically an hour.

column1: Due to its central position in transportation

column1: The city also sells many oranges for which Jeju is famous. Jeju City is surrounded by orange and mandarin farms.Jeju Air has its headquarters in Jeju City.

column1: Jeju City has a humid subtropical climate (Köppen climate classification Cfa) with very warm summers and cool winters. In Holdridge classification
column2: Jeju City has a warm temperate moist forest climate. Due to its location
column3: Jeju City is one of the warmest cities in Korea. However
column4: ocean effect snow brings winter precipitation such as snow showers with strong wind during the winter. Precipitation is significant throughout the year
column5: but is much wetter in summer
column6: with more than 180 millimetres (7.1 in) of rain falling in each month from June to September. The highest temperature ever recorded is 37.5 °C (99.5 °F) on 25 July 1942 while the lowest temperature ever recorded is −6.0 °C (21.2 °F) on 16 February 1977.
